awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Liquid-Based Intelligent High-Frequency Components
awd_abstract_narration:
High-frequency electronic components play an important role in our daily lives. They cover the broad frequency range from radio frequency (RF) to microwave to terahertz (THz). Typical applications include wireless fidelity (Wi-Fi) systems, microwave ovens, bluetooth systems, wireless power transfer, satellite communication, anti-collision car radar, airport security check systems, THz imaging, and many others. With the advent of these systems, high-frequency electronic components are now required to support electronic systems operating in many different frequency bands and with different characteristics. To address this issue, it is important to design and realize high-frequency electronic components with reconfigurable and highly flexible responses (e.g. THz components with tunable frequency band and large modulation depth). Up to now, almost all of such high-frequency components are made of solid materials.  Their physical structures are rigid, fixed and difficult to reconfigure. This research will study novel liquid-based high-frequency electronic components. The employment of liquids to replace conventional solid materials will facilitate the generation of reconfigurable and intelligent electronic systems with high adaptability. The intelligence is enabled by electronically manipulating liquid movements and morphing its shape. The proposed research will pave the way for the development of liquid-based electronic systems.  In addition to advancing knowledge in both science and engineering, the proposed project will have potential broad impacts to our society, including improvements to communication, safety, health care, and defense systems. This project will also produce exciting learning and training opportunities for students.

The explosive development of communication systems in the past decade has imposed stringent design challenges for high-frequency components. For example, the emerging THz technology has called for the innovative design of THz components with advanced functionalities. The proposed project aims to realize efficient use and control of liquid materials to adaptively change the responses of high-frequency devices, from which system level intelligence can be achieved to actively control these devices for optimal performance. Electrowetting on dielectric (EWOD) will be employed as the tuning mechanism to realize agile actuation and programmable transport of liquids. The resulting novel liquid-based high-frequency devices can operate efficiently at the broad spectrum from RF/microwave to THz. By leveraging multi-disciplinary knowledge in electromagnetics and electrowetting techniques, this project has the following three innovations: (1) design of novel liquid-based THz components with transformative characteristics and properties; (2) use of the EWOD technique to realize adaptive tuning of the high-frequency devices with reconfigurable and programmable responses; (3) tuning of high-frequency components through three-dimensional manipulation of liquids. The proposed research represents a systematic and interdisciplinary effort to realize liquid-based high-frequency components with a fully electronically-controlled tuning and flexible properties, covering a broad range of applications such as communications, security, and sensing. The proposed design will be verified by experimental results and module demonstration.

por.por_cntn:
The liquid systems have been widely applied in chemistry, biology and mechanics. Applications vary from chemical assay to biological sample analysis, from mechanical switching to microelectronic cooling, but the liquid systems have seldom been used in constructing high-frequency electromagnetic devices including radio-frequency (RF)/microwave and terahertz (THz) components. Compared with conventional solid materials, liquids provide attractive properties such as flexible geometry and easy circulation; and the soft nature of liquids effectively releases the mechanical stresses associated with the integration and packaging processes. However, it is difficult to electronically control the movement or morphing of liquid materials, which is the major bottleneck in the design of liquid-based electronic devices. In this project, with the aid of electrowetting technique (specifically the electrowetting on dielectric (EWOD) technique), several types of liquid-based wave reflectors have been explored and fabricated to achieve the advantages of fully-electrically controlled tuning. Different liquid materials have been explored to investigate their compatibility for high-frequency applications. We have also investigated different types of electromagnetic devices and components with multi-functions and tunable responses for high-frequency applications.

To control the propagation of high-frequency electromagnetic waves, a liquid-based wave reflector has been designed and fabricated. Specifically, EWOD-based control pads are applied to the sidewalls of this device. By applying suitable control voltages, it can steer the electromagnetic beam in the elevation plane. Next, to enable the wave steering in the horizontal plane, a liquid-based wave reflector featuring specially designed EWOD electrodes (i.e. a rotary electrode pattern) is designed and fabricated. For further realizing the tunable THz devices, different types of THz components with advanced functionality have been studied. We have designed several types of multi-band THz metasurfaces. A dual-band THz metasurface that can work at two arbitrarily selected frequencies has been designed and validated experimentally. By modifying and optimizing this design, we have further achieved a truly single-layer dual-band THz metasurface that can simultaneously manipulate the THz signals at two operating frequencies. Based on the similar design principle, a quad-band THz metasurface that can support four frequency bands has been designed and demonstrated, which is reported for the first time in this field to the best of our knowledge. We have also designed multi-functional THz metasurfaces. Specifically, a dual-mode THz metasurface which can manipulate both transmitted and reflected signals has been designed. Its performance has been validated through numerical simulations. Moreover, we have explored the design of tunable high-frequency devices through novel materials (e.g. graphene) and novel architectures (e.g. new beam-forming networks). The resulting devices are capable of providing the full control of electromagnetic waves in terms of impedance, phase, amplitude, polarization, and working frequency. Overall, through this project, the developed high-frequency devices have shown potentials to enable tunable devices at the THz frequency band and even beyond, which can generate large impacts in areas such as communication systems, sensing, and imaging.  

This project has partially supported four graduate students and one postdoctoral research associate. The research results generated by this project have been integrated into the PIs’ undergraduate-level and graduate-level courses (e.g. antennas). Based on the project results, we have published over 6 journal and conference papers. The research experience gained through this project has inspired us to explore more in the area of tunable electromagnetic devices and systems and make more profound impact to our society.
